details.title: Parameter estimation for a modified Weibull distribution, for progressively type-II censored samples
details.standardTitle: Parameter estimation for a modified Weibull distribution, for progressively type-II censored samples

p: H. K. T. Ng is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Statistical Science at Southern Methodist University. He received his Ph.D. degree in Mathematics (2002) from McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada. He has been at Southern Methodist University since August 2002. His research interests include reliability, nonparametric methods, censored data analysis, and statistical inference. He is a member of the American Statistical Association.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat. Sci., Southern Methodist Univ., Dallas, TX, USA
authors.name: H.K.T. Ng

details.abstract: In this paper, the estimation of parameters based on a progressively Type-II censored sample from a modified Weibull distribution is studied. The likelihood equations, and the maximum likelihood estimators are derived. The estimators based on a least-squares fit of a multiple linear regression on a Weibull probability paper plot are compared with the MLE via Monte Carlo simulations. The observed Fisher information matrix, as well as the asymptotic variance-covariance matrix of the MLE are derived. Approximate confidence intervals for the parameters are constructed based on the s-normal approximation to the asymptotic distribution of MLE, and log-transformed MLE. The coverage probabilities of the individual s-normal-approximation confidence intervals for the parameters are examined numerically. Some recommendations are made from the results of a Monte Carlo simulation study, and a numerical example is presented to illustrate all of the methods of inference developed here.

citations.title: Parameter estimation for a modified Weibull distribution, for progressively type-II censored samples

links.abstract: A new lifetime distribution capable of modeling a bathtub-shaped hazard-rate function is proposed. The proposed model is derived as a limiting case of the Beta Integrated Model and has both the Weibull distribution and Type 1 extreme value distribution as special cases. The model can be considered as another useful 3-parameter generalization of the Weibull distribution. An advantage of the model is that the model parameters can be estimated easily based on a Weibull probability paper (WPP) plot ...

context.text: A three-parameter modified Weibull distribution (MWD) was originally proposed by Lai, Xie, & Murthy [1] as an extension of the Weibull model.
Lai, Xie, & Murthy [1] showed that a MWD fit data with a bathtub-shaped hazard-rate function better than competing models.
Lai, Xie, & Murthy [1] discussed the properties & parameter estimation for the MWD based on a complete sample.
In the complete sample case, Lai, Xie, & Murthy [1] suggested the use of multiple linear regression on a WPP plot to estimate the parameters \$a\$,\$b\$, and \$\lambda\$.
This corrects a mistake in Equation (17) in Lai, Xie, & Murthy [1].
Equations (2.4) –(2.8) correct the errors, and generalize Equation (17)–(21) in [1].
We consider the data from Aarset [15], which were used as an illustrative example by Lai, Xie, & Murthy [1].

references.title: A modified Weibull distribution
references.text: C. D. Lai, M. Xie, D. N. P. Murthy, "A modified Weibull distribution", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 52, pp. 33-37, 2003.

context.text: Some early works on progressive censoring can be found in Cohen [2], [3], Mann [4], and Thomas & Wilson [5].

references.text: D. R. Thomas, W. M. Wilson, "Linear order statistic estimation for the two-parameter Weibull and extreme value distributions from Type-II progressively censored samples", Technometrics, vol. 14, pp. 679-691, 1972.

links.abstract: The problem of evaluating the time-to-failure percentiles in progressively-censored tests on solid insulating materials is addressed. Statistical methods to estimate the parameters of the Weibull distribution (and their confidence limits) are examined on the basis of the results of aging with combined thermal-electrical stresses carried out on XLPE insulated cable models. These tests are performed at the same stresses on samples more than 1 m long and subjected to progressive censoring of aging ...

context.text: A practical application of progressive Type-II censoring on aging tests on solid insulating materials has been illustrated by Montanari & Cacciari [6].

references.title: Progressively-censored aging tests on xlpe-insulated cable models
references.text: G. C. Montanari, M. M. Cacciari, "Progressively-censored aging tests on xlpe-insulated cable models", IEEE Trans. Electrial Insulation, vol. 23, pp. 365-372, 1988.

context.text: Viveros & Balakrishnan [7] proposed a conditional method of inference to derive exact confidence intervals.

references.title: Interval estimation of parameters of life from progressively censored data
references.text: R. Viveros, N. Balakrishnan, "Interval estimation of parameters of life from progressively censored data", Technometrics, vol. 36, pp. 84-91, 1994.

context.text: A book dedicated completely to progressive censoring has been published by Balakrishnan & Aggarwala [8].

references.title: Progressive Censoring: Theory, Methods, and Applications
references.text: N. Balakrishnan, R. Aggarwala, Progressive Censoring: Theory Methods and Applications, 2000, Birkhäuser.

context.text: Recently, the estimation of parameters from different lifetime distributions based on progressive Type-II censored data are studied by many authors including Childs & Balakrishnan [9], Balakrishnan & Kannan [10], Ng, Chan, & Balakrishnan [11], and Balakrishnan et al. [12].

links.abstract: The likelihood equations based on a progressively Type-II censored sample from a Gaussian distribution do not provide explicit solutions in any situation except the complete sample case. This paper examines numerically the bias and mean square error of the MLE, and demonstrates that the probability coverages of the pivotal quantities (for location and scale parameters) based on asymptotic s-normality are unsatisfactory, and particularly so when the effective sample size is small. Therefore, this...

references.title: Point and interval estimation for gaussian distribution, based on progressively type-II censored samples
references.text: N. Balakrishnan, N. Kannan, C. T. Lin, H. K. T. Ng, "Point and interval estimation for gaussian distribution based on progressively type-II censored samples", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 52, pp. 90-95, 2003.

context.text: This procedure can be modified for progressively Type-II censored data by computing the empirical cdf as (see Meeker & Escobar [13])where .

Because \$a\$, \$b\$, and \$\lambda\$ are positive parameters, it is possible to use log transformations to obtain approximate confidence intervals for these parameters (see Meeker & Escobar [13]) by approximating the distribution of \$(\ln(\mathhat{a})-\ln(a))/\sqrt{\mathhat{\sigma} ^{2}(\ln(\mathhat{a}))}\$ by a standard \$s\$-normal distribution, where \${\mathhat{\sigma}}^{2}(\ln(\mathhat{a}))\$ is the estimated variance of \$\ln(\mathhat{a})\$.

references.title: Statistical Methods for Reliability Data
references.text: W. Q. Meeker, L. A. Escobar, Statistical Methods for Reliability Data, 1998.

references.title: A simple simulational algorithm for generating progressive type-II censored samples
references.text: N. Balakrishnan, R. A. Sandhu, "A simple simulational algorithm for generating progressive type-II censored samples", The American Statistician, vol. 49, pp. 229-230, 1995.

links.abstract: The Total Time on Test (TTT) concept is a useful tool in several reliability contexts. This note presents a new test statistic, based on the TTT plot, for testing if a random sample is generated from a life distribution with constant versus bathtub-shaped hazard rate.

context.text: We consider the data from Aarset [15], which were used as an illustrative example by Lai, Xie, & Murthy [1].
We simulated the progressively Type-II right censored sample based on the data from Aarset [15], and the data so obtained are presented in Table X.

references.title: How to identify bathtub hazard rate
references.text: M. V. Aarset, "How to identify bathtub hazard rate", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 36, pp. 106-108, 1987.
